content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice.
I kinda fear that people just will not know when brackets are balanced and when they're not but it's pretty clear from the test cases.

Good edits.

There still "Stack" in the description and the name tho.

Also, the usage of the "palindrome" word here is confusing since no word is a palindrome of another word. Closing parenthesis here is just opening ones but reversed.

I suggest changing Statement to: `
Check for Balanced Brackets/parenthesis in an expression (well-formedness).

In this problem, a word beginning with _ (underscore) is "brackets open." Same word but reversed and with an underscore at the and is "brackets close".
Underscore will not be used anywhere else.

Example: _brackets x + 1 stekcarb_ * y + _parenthesis 7 * 5 sisehtnerap_
Brackets here are balanced.

The math should not be checked, only if the delimiters are balanced.
`
And removing "with stack" from the name. And also removing "palindrome" from one of the tests.

And I need to make it clear that while "do not say players how to solve" is more of my personal liking, usage of "palindrome" instead of "reverse" makes the statement unclear and therefore not viable enough (in my opinion).
It's a nice one, solved it with regex and it's not that complicated if approached well, but I agree to lopidav's suggestions. Once addressed, I'll happily approve.

> no test with `_B` as an input
Disappointing.

Otherwise, pretty cool.
Change the goal so that you're not forcing Stack usage on the players.
I would suggest making the description shorter in general.
Also, here some statement guidelines: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/writing-the-statement#
And it says "Don't address the reader directly" among other things.

If you change anything, ping me, I might approve

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Love this! Solution is simple and elegant when using a stack.

I would prefer if the output was non-binary to prevent guessing players from giving up. "Balanced <number of balanced brackets>" and "Not Balanced <first non-balanced term>". I'm happy to approve as is though. Great job on the test cases, you really thought through ways someone could solve this incorrectly.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this is awesome bro i really love its and its not even that much complicated when you focus on _p and p_ 0 th and last index if both match tata... its balanced

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Too complicated (3 things to do : palindromes, detection of open/close parenthesis well placed, code size) for a 15min
i know i am not smart enough to solve this, whatever nice problem

Hello, 

I am sorry but I found your explanation to complicated compare to the work to be done...
Basically, you want to detect open/close parenthesis or brackets.

So Why don't you just write it with the symbols ? => a + ( b * c ) - 2 - a  instead of a + _Brackets b * c stekcarB_ - 2 - a

2nd point : I have completed the CoC in checking if the number of "_Brackets" is equal to the number of "stekcarB_ " and if  the number of "_Parenthesis" is equal to the number of  "sisehtneraP_". 

So if the equation is written like this  a + _stekcarB_  b * c Brackets - 2 - a or like that _Parenthesis a * b - _Brackets 2 + csisehtneraP_ _stekcarB , the code will not see it, but I will completed the CoC.

Here is my code (in python sorry):

#Get only all the bracket and parenthesis in the line
line =  [i for i in input().split() if i in ['_Brackets', "stekcarB_", "_Parenthesis", "sisehtneraP_" ]]

#Check if the number of open/close brackets are equal  and if the number of open/close parenthesis are equal
if line.count("_Brackets") == line.count("stekcarB_") and line.count("_Parenthesis") == line.count("sisehtneraP_"):
    print("Balanced")
else :
    print("Not Balanced")

An easy test with a little touch of String manipulation.

Could be use in a clash.

I would review the first sentence to make it more clear/direct.
"In this classic [Balanced Brackets] problem, you will have to assert the well-formedness of an expression using [Stack] and others tool to go beyond."

I fallen for the empty stack test on the last validator ;-)

=> So Why don't you just write it with the symbols? Answer: Using only symbols, it is the classic way, there is no challenge. My problem unites the classic problem of balancing parentheses and the verification of palindromes.

=> 2nd point :
Constraints: ALL and only delimiters will contain underscore.

Sorry, my fault, test 5 that should prevent the comparison of the same quantity, I wrote it wrong, thank you very much for the feedback. Now Test 5 does not allow you to compare only if the number is equal.
I'm going to add new test cases to avoid hard coding like that

Glad you agree, thank you.

So to sum up, your CoC test : palindroms, position of parenthesis/brackets and size code ? 

3 things to test in 15min where sometimes the CoC was to work on palindroms only... It will be difficult for non-advanced people to completed it.

Also if you agree with the summary, please simplified your explanation. Some people can have dyslexia  or doesn't speak very well english and it should not be a limitation to code.
Sorry, if you can help me, I'm not an English speaker, I used Google translator
